sen.j: 陣屋（じんや）とは、江戸時代の幕藩体制における大名領（藩）の藩庁が置かれた屋敷、または徳川幕府天領の代官の住居および役所が置かれた建物のことである。
sen.e: A jinya is a residence where a government office of domain (han) of daimyo (territorial lord) under the shogunate system in Edo period was located or a building for residence and office of daikan (local governor) of a tenryo (bakufu-owned land).
sen.cmt: ・「藩庁」は用語集では「government building of domain」ですが、文脈からbuildingではなくofficeとしました。・「江戸時代」はEdo eraとEdo periodの両方が用語集に掲載されていました。以後他の「○○時代」も含め、本や区分ではすべてperiodにしています。
sen.e: A jinya is a residence where a government office was located of the domain (han) of a daimyo (territorial lord) under the shogunate system in the Edo Period, or a building acting as the residence and office of the daikan (local governor) of a tenryo (bakufu-owned piece of land).

A jinya is a residence where a government office was located of the domain (han) of a daimyo (territorial lord) under the shogunate system in the Edo period, or a building acting as the residence and office of the daikan (local governor) of a tenryo (bakufu-owned piece of land).

sen.j: 一般的に3万石以下の城を持たない大名が陣屋を持った。
sen.e: In general a daimyo with income of less than 30,000 goku without a castle owned a jinya.
In general a daimyo with an income of less than 30,000 goku and didn't have a castle owned a jinya.
In general a daimyo with an income of less than 30,000 goku and didn't have a castle owned a jinya.

sen.j: また旗本領や大藩の家老の所領地である知行所の政庁が置かれた屋敷も含まれる。
sen.e: A jinya also means a residence where the government office of chigyosho which is domain of bakufu hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) or karo (chief retainer) of a big domain was located.

A jinya also refers to a residence where the government office of the chigyosho, which is a domain of the bakufu hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) or karo (chief retainer) of a big domain, was located.

A jinya also refers to a residence where the government office of the chigyosho, which is a domain of the bakufu hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) or karo (chief retainer) of a big domain, was located.

sen.j: 所領に飛地を持つ大名が、現地の出張所として陣屋を設置することもあった。
sen.e: A daimyo who has an enclave domain occasionally set up a jinya as a local office in the enclave.
Daimyo having an enclave domain occasionally set up a jinya as a local office in the enclave.

sen.j: また、五稜郭や長崎奉行所なども陣屋として扱われることがある。
sen.e: In addition, Goryokaku and Nagasaki Magistrate's office are sometimes regarded as jinya.
In addition, Goryokaku and Nagasaki Magistrate's office are sometimes regarded as jinya.

sen.j: さらには幕府直轄領地である支配所に置かれた代官所を含む場合もある。
sen.e: Further, magistrate's office at shihaijo which was directly governed by Edo bakufu is considered a jinya in some cases.
Also, the magistrate's office at shihaijo which was directly governed by the Edo bakufu is considered a jinya in some cases.
Also, the magistrate's office at shihaijo which was directly governed by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) is considered a jinya in some cases.

sen.j: なお、陣屋に藩庁を置く大名のこと、無城大名あるいは陣屋大名と呼んだ。
sen.e: A daimyo who had his government office of domain at a jinya was called mujo daimyo (daimyo without castle) or jinya-daimyo.
sen.cmt: ・「藩庁」は用語集では「government building of domain」ですが、文脈からbuildingではなくofficeとしました。
sen.e: Daimyo who had the government office of their domains at a jinya were called called mujo daimyo (daimyo without a castle) or jinya-daimyo.
Daimyo who had the government office of their domains at a jinya were called mujo daimyo (daimyo without a castle) or jinya-daimyo.

sen.j: 無城大名が城主大名城主格大名へ昇格した場合、国許の陣屋を城に転換することは許されず、実際には城門の構築を許されるのみであった。
sen.e: When a mujo daimyo was promoted to a joshu daimyo (governor of a castle) or a joshukaku daimyo (daimyo without castle, but treated almost as joshu daimyo), he was not allowed to convert his local jinya to a castle but actually was allowed to establish a gate only.
sen.cmt: 「城主大名城主格大名」を「城主大名または城主格大名」と読み替えて訳しました。
sen.e: When a mujo daimyo was promoted to joshu daimyo (governor of a castle) or joshukaku daimyo (daimyo without castle, but treated in a similar way to joshu daimyo), he was not allowed to convert his local jinya to a castle but actually was allowed to construct a gate only.

When a mujo daimyo was promoted to joshu daimyo (governor of a castle) or joshukaku daimyo (daimyo without castle, but treated in a similar way to joshu daimyo), he was not allowed to convert his local jinya to a castle but actually was allowed to construct a gate only.

sen.j: 陣屋は、城郭に比べて簡略化されており、行政・居住のみの機能しか持ち合わせていないものが多かった。
sen.e: A jinya was simplified compared to a castle and often had functions for administration and residence only.
A jinya was easy to maintain compared to a castle and often had functions for administration and residence only.

sen.j: 塀や長屋で囲った敷地内または外に、長屋または小屋など、各地で呼び名は異なるところはあるが部下が住まう屋敷と中央となる役所と奥向きである本陣が造られることが多かった。
sen.e: Within or outside of its premises enclosed by walls or nagaya (row house) were residence, called nagaya or koya (small house) depending on the region, in which followers lived, a central office, and an inner part called honjin.
sen.cmt: 「本陣」は用語集では「headquarters of army」とありましたが、陣屋における本陣の意味とは違うと考え、採用していません。
sen.e: Within or outside the area enclosed by walls or nagaya (row houses) were residences called nagaya or koya (small houses) depending on the region, in which followers lived, a central office, and an inner part called the honjin.

sen.j: ところにより、旧城地や城郭のように小高く造る場合もあった。
sen.e: Some jinya were made as high as a castle.
sen.cmt: ・旧城地＝以前城のあった場所と解釈すると、「～のように小高く造る」という日本語と結びつかないため、「城郭」=castleのみ訳出しました。・一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Some jinya were built to the same height as a castle.
Some jinya were built to the same height as a castle.

sen.j: 特に小藩の大名陣屋では、園部城や菰野陣屋（三重県菰野町）のように幕末（明治元年）に至って天守に見立てた櫓や水堀、低い石垣や土塁を築いたり、森陣屋（大分県玖珠町）のように隣接する神社境内に石垣を多用したり、天守に見立てた2階建ての茶屋を建てるなど、城郭を模したものもあった。
sen.e: Especially daimyo jinya of a small domain imitated a castle, for example Sonobe-jo Castle and Komono Jinya (Komono Town, Mie Prefecture) constructed towards the end of Edo period (1868) a turret likened to a tenshu (main keep or tower of a castle), mizubori (water-filled moat), low stone wall, and dorui (earthwork), and Mori Jinya (Kusu Town, Oita Prefecture) had many stone walls in the adjacent shrine and two-storied chaya (tea house) which compared to a tenshu.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文例外対処・「大名陣屋」はここでは一般名詞であると考え、小文字表記にしています。
sen.e: Especially the daimyo jinya of small domains were built in imitation of a castle, for example Sonobe-jo Castle and Komono Jinya (Komono Town, Mie Prefecture) were constructed towards the end of the Edo Period (1868) with a turret likened to a tenshu (main keep or tower of a castle), a mizubori (water-filled moat), low stone walls, and dorui (earthworks), and also Mori Jinya (Kusu Town, Oita Prefecture) had many stone walls in the adjacent shrine and a two-storied chaya (tea house) which was likened to a tenshu.

sen.j: 稜堡式の土塁と砲台を構築した松前藩の戸切地陣屋（北海道上磯町）のように、限定的に軍事機能を持たせることもあった。
sen.e: Some jinya had limited military functions such as Hekirichi Jinya of Matsumae Domain (Kamiiso Town, Hokkaido Prefecture) which had dorui and gun batteries in ryoho-shiki style (a style based on the fortification of Vauban in France).

sen.j: 上総国飯野陣屋、越前国敦賀陣屋、周防国徳山陣屋を三大陣屋という。
sen.e: Iino Jinya of Kazusa Province, Tsuruga Jinya of Echizen Province, and Tokuyama Jinya of Suo Province are the three major jinya.

sen.j: 高山陣屋（岐阜県高山市）飛騨郡代の役所、天領の陣屋として唯一現存している。
sen.e: Takayama Jinya (Takayama City, Gifu Prefecture) is the only remaining jinya which functioned as an office of Hida gundai (a magistrate of Hida region) and jinya of tenryo.

sen.e: Nabari Jinya (Mie Prefecture) is a daimyo jinya, or more precisely a jinya of Nabari Todo family of Todo Clan.

sen.j: 陣屋とは、元々は平安時代に宮中警護をする衛士の詰所のことを陣屋と呼んでいた。
sen.e: A jinya originally meant a tsumesho (a guardroom) for eji (a guard) who guarded the palace in Heian period.
sen.cmt: ・文頭の「陣屋とは」は文末と重複するため訳出していません。・用語集では「詰所」＝「sumesyo (a station)」となっていました。スペルを修正し、またカッコ内の説明も「guardroom」としました。
sen.e: A jinya originally meant a tsumesho (guardroom) for an eji (guard) who guarded the palace in the Heian Period.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代には合戦における兵士の臨時軍営を陣屋と呼んだ。
sen.e: In Kamakura period a jinya meant a temporary military camp for warriors at a battle.
In the Kamakura Period a jinya meant a temporary military camp for warriors during a battle.

sen.j: また、地頭の役所を陣屋とも呼んでいた。
sen.e: An office of jito (manager and lord of manor) was also called a jinya.
An office of a jito (manager and lord of a manor) was also called a jinya.

sen.j: そして近世には民政上の拠点を指す意味が強くなり、幕藩体制における政庁兼居所・蔵を意味する言葉となった。
sen.e: In the early-modern times, a jinya indicated more a base of civil administration and became a word meaning a government office and residence and warehouse under the shogunate system.
